* My first impressions after watching the screenshots and the review:
** I really like the new K-Menu design, although my favorite color is still blue ;)
** Also the new System Settings categorization is very good, although maybe Network Settings and User Management should be placed under Advanced, in my opinion.
** What I really dislike is the new naming scheme in the K-Menu on KDE 3.5.5. I was using the "Name (Description)" scheme, and it was really nice. Now it has been changed to Name Description, which in English is OK, but in some languages that makes it difficult to understand (for example, in Catalan or Spanish, the result is like if we had "Description Name" in English). It is an option to have it this way, but it should be possible to change it back to "Name (Description)".
** And finally, thanks a lot for all your hard work! :) -- EduardErezaMart√≠nez

* I disliked the lipstik theme in Dapper so I always installed and used the klearlook theme for it looks sharper and better. However the install provides plastik now instead. I despise lipstik but plastik looks even worse and is not as configurable. The two themes are similar but lipstik is definitely better. I suggest going back to lipstik or maybe even consider another theme.

* Many of kde's applications have a tool bar on which you can configure. In dapper I fiddled with some of these settings and set the icon size to large. I was amazed by the change it made. I could see the full detail of the buttons and I was able to easily see the icons and click them with my mouse. This also reminds me of nautilus in ubuntu where they have larger icons for greater accessibility. Icons at the large size (32 by 32) are not big, just comfortable. You should consider using this icon size in a default kubuntu install. 

* In settings, Configure konqueror, Web behaviour there is an option under tabbed browsing to hide the tab bar when only one tab is open. I hardly use tabs when browsing files locally for files usually open in separate windows as opposed to a new tab.  I think the tab bar should be hidden for it only takes up space on your browser and opening a new tab will automatically activate the tab bar anyway.

* Ubuntu lets you know what is going on with your computer. For example in ubuntu when you are running low on disk space a little pop up comes up to tell you so. If you have broken packages ubuntu will let you know so through a pop-up bubble. Kubuntu would be great with these little trinkets. 

* Kubuntu needs a program like gdebi which does not let you install external packages unless their dependencies are satisfied.

* Adept should have an "Add Cdrom" option like Synaptic Package Manager. I find it imposible to install packages from the ubuntu alternate cd on my kubuntu installation. 
 
Edgy is looking great. I look forward to the final release. --blue
